claim:
Consider the following background information: A 61-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of abdominal pain and constipation. He reports a 4-day history of steady right lower quadrant pain. He has had one small bowel movement in 4 days. Normally he has a bowel movement once a day. His medical history is notable for poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He takes enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, and atorvastatin. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history and drinks 3-4 beers per day. His diet consists primarily of fast food. His temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C), blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min. A review of the patient’s medical record reveals colonoscopy results from 1 year ago. Relevant findings included multiple small, pedunculated polyps which were removed, multiple colonic mucosal outpouchings, and no other masses.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: This patient"s condition is most strongly associated with Menetrier disease.

supporting.text: Menetrier disease is a rare condition characterized by giant gastric folds and hypoproteinemia, neither of which are mentioned in the patient's presentation.

attacks.text: Menetrier disease is a rare condition characterized by giant gastric folds and hypoproteinemia, neither of which are mentioned in the patient's presentation.
The patient's symptoms and history are more consistent with diverticulitis, which is common in older adults with a poor diet and can present with fever, abdominal pain, and constipation.
Diverticulitis often presents with left lower quadrant pain, not right lower quadrant pain, which reduces the likelihood of this diagnosis.
Right lower quadrant pain could indicate appendicitis, which is a more urgent condition and should be ruled out given the patient's fever and elevated inflammatory markers.
The patient's history of colonic mucosal outpouchings (diverticula) from the colonoscopy makes diverticulitis a plausible diagnosis despite the atypical pain location.

Menetrier disease is extremely rare and typically presents with epigastric pain, hypoalbuminemia, and peripheral edema, none of which are present here.
The patient's history of colonic polyps and diverticulosis increases the likelihood of a colonic source for his symptoms rather than a gastric one.
